div1.p: Your letter and your book have come to me here where I have been staying on for a few days deer hunting after my inspection of the 4th Cavalry. I have been reading the book in the evenings after my return from hunting, and expect to finish it on my way back to Omaha as I am leaving today. I am enjoying the songs immensely. They are superb. I do not know of anyone who has so accurately set history to verse. They remind me of Virgil and Homer, and deserve to be ranked with these classics. It is a real pleasure to read them, and more than that, it is quite evident that they will bear and are worthy of very close study, both from the literary and historical standpoints.

As I said to you, I think that rifle sight is . I know of nothing even approaching it in design, I am not certain, however, that it has successful commercial possibilities. Its adjustments are fixed — that is it does not adjust for zero. It would appear that adjustment for zero, that is adjustment so that it will shoot correctly at 25 yards with the sight set at 25 yards, must be made with the front sight. That is the front sight must be raised or lowered, or moved right or left until the rifle shoots correctly. Then this having been done the rear sight will then proceed to function properly. Now such adjustments of front sight is a difficult problem for the ordinary man. If he wishes to use a bead front sight (and most do) he cannot file down the front sight until it is
47
the right height, but must rather have a number of heights of front bead sights, differing by about 1/50th inch, to try until he gets the correct height. Such adjustment cannot be made at the factory, but must be made by the shooter himself because every individual differs slightly in how he aims. Also every make of ammunition shoots slightly different, with different center of impacts, and differs on different days, and there are many varieties of .22 Long Rifle cartridges with velocities running from 1000 to 1450 f.s. and these all have different trajectories. In addition one cannot select onone specific ammunition in advance for any .22 weapon because some varieties may shoot very poorly and some very accurately in an individual arm.

I am rather taking it for granted that to be successful a sight should cause the rifle and cartridge to shoot close to the mark at say 50 yards when the rear sight is set at 50 yards. Now our experience has been that with .22 cal weapons the only way to accomplish this is to set up a target at 50 yards each morning before one starts out shooting and zero the rifle in. That having been done by the individual shooter for that day, and that ammunition, it will remain quite constant during the day if the temperature does not change materially. But a rifle zeroed on one day may be found to shoot as much as 2Â½ inches off on another day at 50 yards, or if the ammunition be changed, as much as 6 to 8 inches. Daily zeroing seems to be essential to close and successful shooting with the .22 rifle, and that is why we who know rifle use sights adjusting to half minutes for elevation and windage.
I hope you will stop in to see me when West in Omaha.
